claim: France uses the euro as its official currency

supporting.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency on January 1, 1999, replacing the French franc.

attacks.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency on January 1, 1999, replacing the French franc.
Some regions of France, such as New Caledonia and French Polynesia, do not use the euro as their official currency.
New Caledonia and French Polynesia are overseas territories of France, not part of metropolitan France, where the euro is the official currency.
The euro is not the only legal tender in France; some businesses may accept other currencies like the US dollar in tourist areas.
Acceptance of other currencies in tourist areas is informal and not legally mandated; the euro remains the sole official currency of France.

supporting.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in France, as it is a member of the Eurozone.

attacks.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in France, as it is a member of the Eurozone.
Some overseas territories of France, such as French Polynesia, do not use the euro but instead use the CFP franc.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and is effectively under the monetary policy of the European Central Bank, maintaining the euro's influence.

supporting.text: The European Central Bank oversees monetary policy for France, as it uses the euro.

attacks.text: The European Central Bank oversees monetary policy for France, as it uses the euro.
France could theoretically leave the Eurozone and revert to a national currency, as seen with Brexit.
Leaving the Eurozone would require significant political and economic upheaval, making it highly unlikely in the near term.
Some overseas territories of France, like French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
French overseas territories using the CFP franc are exceptions, as mainland France and most regions use the euro as the official currency.

supporting.text: French businesses and government transactions are conducted in euros, confirming its status as the official currency.

attacks.text: French businesses and government transactions are conducted in euros, confirming its status as the official currency.
Some French overseas territories, such as French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and used only in specific overseas territories, while mainland France exclusively uses the euro.
Certain businesses in border regions may accept other currencies like Swiss francs or US dollars for convenience.
Accepting other currencies does not change the official status of the euro, as legal tender laws still require euro acceptance.
